description.value: If the [[lookup @name lowercase]] fails a save, it can choose to succeed instead.
The dragon uses its Frightful Presence. It then makes one Bite attack and two Claw attacks. It can replace its Bite attack with a use of Sleep Breath, if available.
Melee Weapon Attack: [[/attack]], reach 10 ft., one target. Hit: [[/damage average]] damage.
Melee Weapon Attack: [[/attack]], reach 5 ft., one target. Hit: [[/damage average]] damage.
Melee Weapon Attack: [[/attack]], reach 15 ft., one creature. Hit: [[/damage average]] damage.

The dragon magically transforms into a Beast or Humanoid that has a challenge rating no higher than its own, or back into its true form, which is Dragon. Any equipment it is wearing or carrying transforms with it or is borne by the new form (the dragon’s choice). It reverts to its true form if it dies. In a new form, the dragon retains its Legendary Resistance trait and its HP, ability to speak, proficiencies, and INT, WIS, and CHA scores, as well as this bonus action. Its statistics and capabilities are otherwise replaced by those of the new form, except any class features or legendary actions of that form.
The [[lookup @name lowercase]] automatically detects every creature and trap within 30 feet of it, pinpointing the current location of each.

The dragon exhales sleep gas in a 60-foot cone. Each creature in that area must succeed on a [[/save format=long]] or fall &Reference[unconscious]{unconscious} for 5 minute. This effect ends for a creature if the creature takes damage or another creature uses an action to wake it.

After the [[lookup @name lowercase]] uses its Fire Breath, the air around it is devoid of moisture and lacking in breathable air. While the [[lookup @name lowercase]]'s Fire Breath is unavailable, each creature that requires air to breathe, other than the [[lookup @name lowercase]], and that starts its turn within 20 feet of the [[lookup @name lowercase]] must succeed on a [[/save format=long]] or begin suffocating. A creature that fails this save for two consecutive rounds falls &Reference[unconscious]{unconscious} until it takes damage or another creature uses an action to wake it.

Note: See hidden text for Suffocation rules.

Suffocating

Most creatures, particularly most PCs, need to breathe air to survive. When a creature can’t breathe, such as while submersed in water, it must hold its breath.

A creature can hold its breath for a number of minutes equal to 1 + its CON modifier (minimum of 30 seconds).

When a creature runs out of breath or is choking, it can survive for a number of rounds equal to its CON modifier (minimum of 1 round). If it is still out of air at the start of its next turn, it drops to 0 HP and begins making death saves. The creature can’t regain hit points or be stabilized until it can breathe again.

For example, a creature with a CON modifier

The [[lookup @name lowercase]] roars at up to two creatures of its choice within 120 feet of it. Each target must succeed on a [[/save]] save or be vulnerable to fire damage until the end of its next turn. A target resistant to fire damage isn’t resistant to it for the duration. A target immune to fire damage is still immune to it, even if the target fails the save.

The [[lookup @name lowercase]] beats its wings. Each creature within 10 feet of the [[lookup @name lowercase]] must succeed on a [[/save]] save or take [[/damage average]] damage and be knocked &Reference[prone]{prone}. The [[lookup @name lowercase]] can then fly up to half its flying speed without provoking opportunity attacks.

Every creature of the [[lookup @name lowercase]]’s choice within 120 ft. of it must succeed on a [[/save]] save or become &Reference[frightened]{frightened} of the [[lookup @name lowercase]] for 1 minute. A creature can repeat the save at the end of each of its turns, ending the effect for itself on a success. If a creature’s save succeeds or the effect ends for it, the creature is immune to the [[lookup @name lowercase]]’s Frightful Presence for the next 24 hours.

The [[lookup @name lowercase]] exhales fire in a 90-foot line that is 5 feet wide. Each creature in that line must make a [[/save format=long]], taking [[/damage average]] damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one.
